body: @fereenwong can you test against COCO to see what the effect of your change is on mAP?

@fereenwong the mAP produced by this repo has been validated against pycocotools to within 1%:
https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov3#map

You can see at 416 pixels, we report 0.57 mAP, and pycocotools analysis of our JSON returns 0.565. At 608 pixels we report 0.611 mAP vs pycocotools 0.608.

If your proposed change causes our mAP to deviate substantially from pycocotools, we naturally can not accept it.

@glenn-jocher
I made a mistake since the index bi is changed when I modify the code:
iou, bi = bbox_iou(pbox, tbox).max(0)
as below:
iou, bi = bbox_iou(pbox, tbox[tcls == pcls]).max(0)

And I found that something changed in line 128 in test.py:
`if iou > iou_thres and bi not in detected:  # and pcls == tcls[bi]:
        correct[i] = 1
        detected.append(bi)`

Then, I did a test with the commented condition as below:
`if iou > iou_thres and bi not in detected and pcls == tcls[bi]:
                        correct[i] = 1
                        detected.append(bi)`
The mAP drops to 53.3

@fereenwong yes I tried this change, but like you said the mAP drops (from 0.570 to 0.546) compared to the pycocotools mAP (0.565), so the alignment is closer without the update. I'm not sure of the cause.

rename.from: The evaluation may not be right

issue.title: A problem in test.py?

labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

repository.name: yolov3
repository.description: YOLOv3 in PyTorch > ONNX > CoreML > TFLite

issue.body:
line in 125 : iou, bi = bbox_iou(pbox, tbox).max(0)

Why do you take the largest index value that overlaps an anchor with the GTs IOU? For example, when two objects are close together, if the two objects are IOU 0.98 and 0.93 respectively, but the categories of the two are different, 0.93 is correct. If the index is the largest, the correct answer is discarded.so i think it's not robust!

body: @fereenwong this should be fixed now in commit https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov3/commit/e1850bf2342934ad85d129c26bf8023215c4aa03.

mAP bug is resolved with commit https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov3/commit/84f0df6c34dbfcd6431f78db9e736fc558f6396f. Problem was continuous integral vs 101-point interpolated integral (COCO method). 

UPDATE: mAP only matches at 0.001 conf-thres, but computes much higher at 0.1 conf-thres. Problem remains.
